data.title: All the Disney+ Shows and Movies Available Now
data.meta_description: Disney Plus is here, featuring originals like 'The Mandalorian', along with classics like 'The Lion King' and Pixar's 'Toy Story.'
data.text:
Disney's streaming platform, Disney+, is here!

It features original series and television, in addition to existing Disney-owned content as well (such as Marvel and Star Wars movies).

Here is every show, movie, and TV movie available on Disney+.

Fellow cord cutters, the golden age of television is among us. Sure, we've already got Netflix, Hulu, Amazon Prime, HBOGo, and numerous others, with Apple TV and Warner Media's HBO Max on the way soon as well. But now leading the wave during this era of social distancing is Disney's new streaming service, appropriately called Disney+.

The biggest draw, initially, may be the fact that the platform hosts content that already exists from studios owned by Disney. What does that mean exactly? It means that your favorite programs from the Pixar, Marvel, and Star Wars franchises will all live here. Additionally, since Disney now owns 20th Century Fox, The Simpsons' entire catalogue lives here as well.

And with all these properties comes a myriad of amazing titles to entertain you, the kids, and the kid in you. Here is everything available to stream now.

Sign up for 7-Day free Disney+ Trial here.

Disney + Originals

One of the biggest draws for Disney+ will also be—like Hulu, which Disney also owns—original series and films. There's a lot of exciting stuff on the horizon to look out for, including a number of series coming from Marvel-verse, like The Falcon and The Winter Soldier, Loki, WandaVision, and more. In the meantime, let's take a look at the Disney+ shows (and movies!) made a splash when the platform launched.

The Mandalorian (series)

Cast: Pedro Pascal, Giancarlo Esposito, Carl Weathers, Gina Carano, Taika Waititi

What's it all about? Set between Return of the Jedi and The Force Awakens, the first season of The Mandalorian—the first ever live-action Star Wars series—debuted and wrapped up last winter. With Jon Favreau (who directed Iron Man and The Lion King) as showrunner, the show follows Pascal (Game of Thrones' Oberyn Martell) as the titular Mandalorian, which probably sounds familiar because he is quite similar to a past Star Wars character you might remember: Boba Fett.

High School Musical: The Musical: The Series (series)

Cast: Joshua Bassett, Olivia Rodrigo, Matt Cornett, Kate Reinders, Julia Lester

What's it all about? You remember the original High School Musical? Don't lie, you do. You're probably singing one of the songs as you read this. The star of the original may be one of our favorite guys these days, but this series pushes a new generation to the forefront, with a particularly meta twist. And yes, the title is no mistake: this is a series about a fictional high school putting on a high school musical production of—you guessed it—High School Musical.

The World According to Jeff Goldblum (series)

Cast: Jeff Goldblum (uhhh, of course)

What's it all about: From National Geographic (also owned by Disney), this genius travel series will follow the legendary actor (star of Jurassic Park, The Fly, and Thor: Ragnarok, among other classics) as he, well, does just about any and everything. From tattoos to ice cream, each episode finds him exploring a topic without any prior research: going on camera with only his life experience and immense charm. What a glorious premise.

Lady and the Tramp (film)

Cast: Tessa Thompson, Justin Theroux, Janelle Monáe, Ken Jeong, Sam Elliott

What's it all about: This 'live action' remake of an animated Disney classic (following the heels of The Lion King, Aladdin, The Jungle Book, etc.) is the classic animal-centric love story. Disney got quite the charming cast for the ride, too, as Lady and the Tramp are voiced by Tessa Thompson and Justin Theroux, respectively. That's one cool pair of dogs, if you ask us.

Diary of a Future President (series)

Cast: Gina Rodriguez, Tess Romero, Selenis Leyva, Charlie Bushnell, Michael Weaver

What's it all about: Have you ever imagined what the world would be like if a woman was the President of the United States? Well, this series tells the tale of a young Cuban-American girl going through the trials of being a teenager, but with the ultimate career goal—a desire to become the Commander in Chief one day. And for those who are looking to get their Gina Rodriguez fix after binge-watching Jane the Virgin? Well, look no further, as she both has a role and executive produces the series. Talk about big shoes to fill.

Sign up for Disney+ Here

Disney Animated Movies

Disney's animated film catalogue goes all the way back to 1937, when the world had only been at war once and when animation required hand-drawing every damn panel (it actually paid off.) Your kids and nieces and nephews probably know all of these, but if you're looking for timeless quality to throw on while you're stuck in quarantine, we recommend Aladdin (1992), Big Hero 6 (2014), Moana (2016), and Atlantis: The Lost Empire (2001).

Disney Live Action Movies (Including 20th Century Fox)

Believe it or not, the Disney live action collection actually dwarfs its animated counterpart. (Pun intended.) While its recent efforts, including dead-eyed Dumbo and expressionless Lion King, might steer you away from anything not animated, it's best to remember that Disney was producing originals for decades before the cannibalization began. For sports fans there's Remember the Titans (2000), Miracle (2004), and The Sandlot (1993). Even the die-hard musical theater fans have a place in Disney culture with Newsies (1992) and its Broadway counterpart (2017). And that's almost an argument in itself.

Disney TV Shows

Age-appropriate television does not mean that it's meant for kids only. Many of these you'll probably be watching with your kids as you try desperately to not pull out your hair. But some are just as much for adults as kids. For a surprisingly dark, always-funny Twin Peaks-esque series, check out Gravity Falls (2012).

Star Wars

For many of you, this is the reason you're getting Disney+ (don't lie—we know the truth). Aside from every installment, prequel, sequel, and prequel sequels (Rogue One) the franchise has to offer, there's also the Clone Wars series. We recommend this one.

Here they all are . . .
